title: 108_hr5182
content: The Homeland Security Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Protection Act of 2004 ensures that civil rights and liberties are not compromised in homeland security efforts. It also establishes an Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties within the Department of Homeland Security. Section 705(a) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to require individuals to report directly to the Secretary and address concerns of profiling on the basis of race, ethnicity, or religion. Additionally, it mandates assistance in developing, implementing, and reviewing policies within the Department. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to require reporting directly to the Secretary on profiling concerns and assisting in developing, implementing, and reviewing Department policies. The amendment also includes overseeing compliance with civil rights and civil liberties requirements and coordinating with other officials on related programs and policies. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to address civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy concerns in an integrated manner. Congress receives appropriate reports on programs and policies, and investigations are conducted on complaints of possible abuses unless determined by the Inspector General. SEC. 4. PROTECTION OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND CIVIL LIBERTIES BY OFFICE OF INSPECTOR GENERAL. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a section on the protection of civil rights and civil liberties by the Office of Inspector General. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security designates a senior official to coordinate investigations of civil rights abuses and receive complaints regarding such abuses by department employees or contractors. The Office of Inspector General ensures effective investigations of civil rights abuses by Department of Homeland Security employees or contractors, consulting with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties for policy recommendations. The Office of Inspector General collaborates with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to investigate alleged abuses of civil rights and provide policy recommendations. They also ensure public access to information on filing complaints or comments regarding civil rights and civil liberties matters. The Office of Inspector General collaborates with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to investigate civil rights abuses and provide policy recommendations. They ensure public access to information on filing complaints and the status of investigations initiated in response to public complaints. Additionally, they are required to report any weaknesses, problems, and deficiencies within the Department related to civil rights or civil liberties. The Office of Inspector General works with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to investigate abuses and make policy recommendations. They ensure public access to complaint filing information and investigation status. Additionally, they report Department weaknesses related to civil rights or civil liberties. SEC. 5 establishes a Privacy Officer. SEC. 5 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 establishes a Privacy Officer who reports directly to the Secretary. The Privacy Officer coordinates with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to ensure that programs, policies, and procedures involving civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy are addressed comprehensively and that appropriate reports are provided to Congress.
